content:
I've edited the statement just now:
* Goal and Constraints sections: reformatted all instructions as {{constants}} and removed half of the monospace formatting because the text may not be shown in full

* Tags: removed "Indexation"

I really wish that the data had been supplied AFTER the code

I've written a compiler in C that cross-compiles the MCxxx code into native x86 code, marks the section as executable and then calls it.  Thus executing the MCxxxx program on the ia64 CPU directly.

But... there's a slight problem with the contribution.  The unusual order of the inputs.  Data first, then code?

By the time we receive the code, the data has already been removed from the stdin.  So, I can't create solutions that read from stdin... it has to read from a buffered version, which kind of sucks.

The error requirements also require buffering the output too.

I imagine that most people attempting this type of challenge would want the data to be provided AFTER the code, so that their solution can process directly from the input stream.

Just a minor grumble, admittedly.  But it would make sense to provide inputs in the order they are most likely to be used.

But, hey, it's here now - and it IS a good challenge : )))

Well done Exanc!  10/10

Edited to fix several typos.

The current dgt description is not clear/accurate:
> Isolate the specified digit of the value of the first operand in the acc register
(it's not a "digit of the value of the first operand" but a digit of acc that gets isolated)
It seems that acc and dat are initialized to 0 but I cannot see this written anywhere. Could you add it to the statement please (or make it more visible if it's written but I missed it)?
I changed the variable name i for nbi in the stub cause it created conflict with the loop variable (named also i by default).
Congratulations for this great job ! I think it is not a medium but hard one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, seems very good, awesome job.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, very fun to play,  with a lot of tests for each type of commands.
The explanations are very good, and helped me a lo to solve this puzzle, it was almost as if I had the algorithm given to me. So I think 'Medium' difficulty may be enough.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great !

Hi 
I solved this problem, it was fun. You worked hard on those test cases ! I have some comments on the description  :
- After the sentence "Please note that some instructions of this language will not be included ..." you should add something like "all instructions below are necessary for this puzzle" because I was not sure.
- in the "mul" instruction it is not clear that the result is stored in acc
- for the "dgt" instruction you should use the same syntax as for "dst" so : "Isolate the digt of acc specified by the first operand"
- for "dgt" and "dst" you could precise "decimal" digit
- I would move the "captions" section before the instructions 
- I deduced it, but it is not clear that the "-" instructions are enabled when the tests are false
- It could be added that the tests applies to all the next "+/-" instructions and not only the next one.
- The variables in the "input" section (l, InputData, N and LineOfCode) should be the same as in the stub generator (d,x0,n,INSTRUCTION)
- In the first test case which appears as an example, I would choose a number different than 1 for the input so there it is easier to understand what is going on.

Nothing there is major, just some fine tuning. I will let you polish this before I approve. Nice job
Adam

hello Exanc.
In the "3rd grade arithmetics" tests, there's a weird:
mul dat acc
There should not be a second 'acc' operand, right?
I haven't tried it yet. soon :-)
Fixed "substract" and  "executued" in statement, plus "interger" in input description.

+1 for SHENZHEN I/O!

There is a mistake in the constraints section within dgt/dst special case:
In "With 0 ≤ A ≤ 3 and 0 ≤ B ≤ 9" --> must be "0 ≤ A ≤ 2"

Also there is "dgt 3" in "Digit manipulation I TEST"
re: "thrust me, you'll love it"?  Is that intentional?

I love controller emulation !

You have a typo in the example : If we execute the opration <-- operation
In the instructions sections, the text does not wrap so I can't see the end of the longer lines.
Please note that the "@" prefix is not included in the official documentation.

Any constructive feedback (positive or negative) will be appreciated.

For anyone that doesn't know about the MCxxxx language already, please refer to the official documentation (you can also read the test cases). This documentation will also help you check if I didn't miss anything.
Yes, this is very frustrating that monospced text doesn't have any linewraping.
Thanks for the feedback, I fixed the issue.
yes
Thanks for the feedback, I tried to fix the issues but i got Network Erro: 504. I'll retry tomorow.
You're correct that's invalid syntax, thanks for the double checking. I hope you'll like the puzzle.

Thanks for your feedback, I appreciate it!
As for your suggestions, I more or less applied then with some twits to make them more concurent with my vision of what I whant this puzzle to be. They were all great anyways.

I hope you'll like the new version!

Thanks for the validation.
As for the difficulty of the puzzle, mediun might be good, the only real challenge here is understanding all the constraints and how branching code works (not even error handling). So I'm changing it to medium.

Thank you :)
As discussed before, I decided to make this puzzle a medium difficulty one.
I changed it to k because numeric constants are often named k. I also changed the input description and constraints accordingly.
It wasn't written anywhere so I added it to the constraints.
Looks like I'm bad at copying documentation :/

Thank you, I just tried to do my best with the limitations of the I/O Puzzle. Buffering the input and output didn't seem as an annoyance for me.

What kind of monster builds a compiler just for one puzzle XD

I did one for the "What the BrainF**k" puzzle :
https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/what-the-brainfuck

I did it because I'd never tried to write a compiler before.  It turned the Easy into a Hard for no reason, but it was a lot of fun.

Now, whenever I see an interpreter, I write a compiler : )

Anyway... Thanks for introducing me to Shenzen IO and for posting one of the best puzzle contributions I've seen so far.

I can't wait to see what you submit next.
I'm just waiting for a good idea to come next ;)
You're a great tester.

This looks great ! You made me discover Shenzhen I/O and I'm hooked !! 
In "conditional execution" I like the new sentence you added to explain more the + and - instructions, but I think you meant "except for TCP" instead of "except for TGT". Also you could add "respectively" at the end of the sentence.
And I still think that the sentence explaining the dgt instruction is not clear, but maybe it's me.
Approved !
Adam
You're right, it's supposed to be TCP.
Issues fixed.
ok, my bad there was a typo.
Whew!  I was feeling stupid there for not getting the joke! :)
You should be able to read everything now. But it's not optimal as everyone has a different font size depending on their personnal settings.
